episode.title: Bates v. State Bar of Arizona

section.heading: Argument of William C. Canby, Jr.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We will hear arguments next in 76-316, Bates and others against the State Bar of Arizona.
Mr. Canby, you may proceed whenever you are ready.

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.

This case is about two lawyers who advertised in their local newspaper and were disciplined for it; but as I intend to show, it is also a case about the delivery of legal services in the United States.

The question presented here is whether a disciplinary rule, Rule 2-101b of the Code of Professional Responsibility, which is embodied in a rule of the Arizona Supreme Court, violates the First Amendment or is invalid for conflict with the Federal antitrust laws.
The rule itself prohibits any attorney from publicizing himself or his partner in local newspapers, among other things.
It has set forth at Pages 3 and 4 of our brief.
The facts which gave rise to this controversy concern a very unusual law practice.

Mr. Bates and Mr. O’Steen, by graduation from law school, worked for about a year-and-a-half, for the Maricopa County Legal Aid Society and then set out on their own to develop a very special kind of practice, which they intended to aim at that group of people who were above the poverty line and not eligible for legal services, but are below the level of affluence which the regular users at the legal profession enjoy.

Consequently, they set up a firm, which was organized to do a business depending greatly on systems where the attorneys set up forms of their own design, used paralegals to a great extent, used automated equipment and, most important of all, charged very low profit for each case.

As a result, we were able to offer a fairly narrow line of services which lent themselves to standardization; but they found a great deal of difficulty in getting the word out, and in the course of a two-year period, their practice did not thrive.

They wanted to make it thrive and they wanted to produce the services and they wanted to have clients, so they put together an advertisement, which appears at Page 409 of the printed Appendix, and they run it in the Arizona Republic, a newspaper of general circulation in Phoenix, Arizona.

This advertisement, among other things, advertised uncontested divorce -- both spouses signed papers -- $175 plus a stated court filing fee; name change for a stated fee; uncontested adoptions and bankruptcies for stated fees; and an uncontested divorce where the attorneys would prepare all the papers for a person who was intent upon getting his own divorce himself.
This was published, and as a result of it, disciplinary proceedings were started by the State Bar of Arizona.
Hearings were held and the Administrative Committee which first heard the case found that they had violated the law.

They permitted a full record to be made, but their finding was simply that the Rule of the Arizona Supreme Court had been breached by the publication and that the two appellants here should be suspended from practice for six months.
On appeal to the Board of Governors of the State Bar of Arizona, this was modified to a week’s suspension for each.
And when it went to the Supreme Court of Arizona, that was changed to a censure; but the finding that they had violated the canon was upheld and a censure was ordered by the Supreme Court of Arizona.
The Supreme Court, in their opinion, specifically rejected the First Amendment claims and the antitrust claims which appellants here had asserted.
Now, a restraint on this kind of advertising, of course, strikes appellants as a severe interference, a classic interference with the communication of information to their clients.
And as I say, their clients were ones who are perhaps the great middle mass, by and large, of the population.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You mean the files, Mr. Canby, or you mean the potential clients?

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: Potential clients, Mr. Chief Justice.

And I might add that an American Bar Foundation study, the Curran and Spalding study which is cited in our brief, indicates that one-third of all the adult Americans never use a lawyer in their lifetimes; another third do so once.

And it also indicates that a great number of people in the United States do not know how to find a lawyer, they do not have regular contacts with lawyers, and they also do not have a very good idea, many of them, of what lawyers charge for their services.
And in fact, a good portion of them tend to overestimate the cost of lawyer services.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Canby, you have emphasized the modest-means type of client.
The firm was also in the business of representing plaintiffs in personal-injury cases.
Did they draw any line with respect to the economic status of that type of client?

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: No, Mr. Justice, and I hasten to add that they did not draw an economic line with any client.
The record indicates that the overwhelming majority of their clients range from the poverty level practically up to very few with incomes over $25,000 a year for a family.
But they do not have a policy of turning away people who have a greater income than that for any case.
The first contention which we assert here is that this provision violates the First Amendment.

And of course on a Commercial-Speech Doctrine, we rely very heavily on Bigelow v. Virginia, which upheld the First Amendment right to advertise an abortion service, and we also rely, of course, very heavily on the decision last term in Virginia State Board of Pharmacy, which held that there was a First Amendment Right for drug-price advertising, that case being brought by consumers who wanted to know drug prices.
But I submit that all of the elements which the Court found commanded First Amendment protection in Virginia State Board of Pharmacy are present in this case.

In other words, the great public interest in the economic allocation of resources, the importance of economic information, and particularly price information, to the consumer in making up his decision as to whether or not to avail himself of legal services and what attorney to get are served by the kind of ad that my clients ran.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Canby, would they have a First Amendment Right to advertise the quality of their services?

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: I think they would if it is not deceptive and misleading, and I believe that --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: For example, in the personal-injury phase of it, would they have a right to give a list of their recent verdicts they just recovered?

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: I think that the Bar, Mr. Justice Stevens, could regulate in ways that the Federal Trade Commission sometimes regulates to make a full disclosure.

In other words, if they gave ten recent recoveries that were very high, this, it seems to me, could be misleading if it gave a false idea of their practice, or it might even be argued that it overstates the role of the attorneys in getting those judgments.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Assume it is completely factual.
The last twenty cases we tried had the following results: nine of them were settled, four of them we lost, and in seven of them we got $200,000 verdicts.

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: I think there would be a First Amendment Right to make that kind of an advertisement, assuming that the last 20 cases was the beginning of a run of good luck.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Mr. Canby, the only thing this case involved is the total and complete ban on advertising.

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: That is correct, Mr. Justice.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That is all we have here now.

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: And that is correct, and no advertising by an individual attorney in a newspaper is permitted in Arizona or, indeed, in the classified sections.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You do not take the position that it cannot be regulated.

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: I do not.
In fact, I am sure that false and misleading advertising can be regulated.
I am also --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You are suggesting, I take it, that they could advertise that they got a $200,000 verdict, that that would be protected by the First Amendment?

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: I think that there is a danger of under-disclosure in that, Mr. Chief Justice, and I think that the Bar could reasonably regulate to require full disclosure effects like that.
I think occasionally a single fact that is advertised could be misleading, even if technically accurate.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But let us test out your view of the scope of the First Amendment protection.
Could they, in describing in an ad the settlement for $200,000, document it with a copy of the check, the settlement check?

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: Here again, Mr. Chief Justice, in my opinion they could if it were not misleading in other ways; but, of course, no one has to go that far to rule that the ad which the appellants put in the newspaper is protected by the First Amendment.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, in a case where there is what is regarded by some as an opening wedge, don't you think these are appropriate areas to explore?

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: Undoubtedly they are, and that is why I say I think that a good deal more advertising and a good variety of it would be entitled to First Amendment protection.
There are others who do not go that far, but I do.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Canby, in endeavoring to have some conception of the scope of the First Amendment right that you are setting, you have been asked questions about the type of advertisements.
Would there be any limitation as to the means?
What about television, for example?

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: I think that television advertising would be protected.
It seems to me that the tests of Virginia State Board of Pharmacy are: does this serve to get information to the consumer?
Is there a First Amendment Right to convey this information?
And television, particularly with a certain segment of the population, would be a very good way to get the availability of certain legal services made known to the population.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It is often said in our profession that the best place to reach prospective personal-injury plaintiffs is in the hospital.

What do you think of, say, handbills that had the information you said a little while ago would be protected by the First Amendment, that is, the number of successful verdicts and the average size of verdicts being handed out in the emergency room?

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: I think that is purely prohibitable.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Why?

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: It seems to me there is a time-place-and-manner regulation that could be made here, and it could be based on a high interest in protecting people who are in various stages of physical disarray, really, from being importune by advertisements.
I think it is important to get information to people, but I do not think that hospital emergency rooms and scene of accidents is the place.
And if the Bar prohibited that, but let general public advertising go, it seems to me that kind of a narrow regulation could be permitted.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Yet you would not say that the State could prohibit a candidate for office from canvassing in a hospital, just because the people might not be in the best possible shape, would you?

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: Correct, Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Was this because you think the protection accorded to this type of speech is less than that accorded to political speech?

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: I think it is.
I think that the circulation of a commercial handbill is entitled certainly to less protection than First Amendment speech of a political nature, and I would not assume the same test.

For instance, false and deceptive political speech is obviously not prohibitable; but I do think, however, that false and deceptive advertising should be and that it is not protected by First Amendment.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, the last term’s case said as much, didn't it ?

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, it did.
I do not think that the… and of course in your concurrence, that was clearly --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: In Pharmacy -- beg your pardon?

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: Yeah, that was clearly stated in more than one of the opinions in that case that because of the likelihood that commercial speech will not be killed and the fact that the facts are really within the peculiar knowledge of the advertiser that probably some different rules can be made, and false and misleading advertising regulation is one of them.
I think it is important to add in this case, too, that the practice of appellants does serve consumers, and it seems that it serves them in obtaining what really is a constitutional right.
I think there is a constitutional right to legal services.

And extending the access to legal services is really a way of saying that the constitutional rights of the recipients will accord with the constitutional rights of the would-be commercial speakers in this case.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Are you suggesting that the function of a pharmacist is to be equated with the function of a physician or a lawyer?

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: No, Mr. Chief Justice.

I think that physicians and lawyers clearly have a much greater variety of services they dispense, there is a great deal of more judgment involved; but the American Medical Association, for instance, has taken a position contrary to the State of Arizona here.

The Governing Council of the American Medical Association this year held that physicians can advertise fees for specific services, and that ruling is set out in the Appendix to their amicus brief, the American Medical Association.

In other words, they did not see it as inconsistent with professionalism of the most discretionary sort to advertise a set fee for a set service and, in fact, set fees are even permitted by the American Bar Association.
In its 1975 amendments, it authorized attorneys to advertise in the classified pages that a written list of fees is available on request.

Well, if an attorney can make up a written list of fees and give it to people who see reference to it in an advertisement, I see no reason why that written list cannot simply be advertised and make the consumer have that information at much greater ease.
But the set fee is still there and it has written down, and it has chosen by the attorney.
On the side of the State in the First Amendment question, there is really here quite a burden to be sustained.

I think that Bigelow and the State Board of Pharmacy are clear that there is a very high State interest required that since the protection does extend to commercial speech, the First Amendment tilts in favor of publication and a State really ought to show interests which justify the prohibition of all of this information.

The first justification, which is heavily urged by the appellee in this case, is that this is really a form of barratry; that if advertisements are widespread, then people who would not have availed themselves of legal services will do so.
And if that is the definition of barratry, then we simply have to face that and say we are guilty, because ignorance is not a very good way to control who uses the legal system.

And to say that those who know they have causes of action or those who know they need wills or those who know they need divorces can get them, but those who do not know this cannot and that that is the way we control the flow of litigation or the use of legal services.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, haven't Bar Associations as such for many, many years issued free brochures explaining the Rule problem and explaining joint tenancy, explaining the problems of acquiring and financing the purchase of a home and issuing them in public places without directing anyone to a particular lawyer, but merely acquainting the public with these kinds of services?

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: They have.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: That has been very common, hasn't it?

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: They have, and you are right, Mr. Chief Justice, this has been going on for several years.
But the great need is still there.

The studies, the preliminary report's a couple of years old, and the final report of this legal-needs-of-the-public survey is due for publication by the American Bar Foundation this coming February, next month, and it indicates that the people really are not being reached by this information.
And they are certainly not being reached by price information.
People do not know what this costs, and it is very burdensome to find out what it costs.
And when you find out what a lawyer is going to charge, there is no way of telling what other lawyers charge for anything like this service.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Yeah, but don't these same Bar Associations, usually the state and local as distinguished from the American Bar, publish recommended schedules of fees, not binding as in the Goldfarb Case, but merely communicating to the public that the examination of a title has a certain range, that probate of an estate has a certain figure, preparing a deed or a will, etcetera?

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: There is no evidence in the record of this, and I do not know of it is being done in Arizona.
It may well have been done elsewhere.
I just cannot answer the question.
I do not know.

It seems to me there might be antitrust problems with those fees if it is used as a means of agreeing on fees to be charged; but to my knowledge, at least in the record in this case, there is no indication this has been done.

I think the reason that these institutional efforts, although they are very helpful, really have not succeeded are two: one is that they do not permit enough information to be conveyed; and second, it is a limited effort, because it is really not directly in the economic interest of those disseminating the information to disseminate it.
And because of that, the efforts do not work as well as they do when the person who is disseminating has as personal interest in getting the message across.
Another argument that is used by the State, although I should say before I bring this one up that we are talking here about the State interests which might support this kind of a regulation.

We are not talking about anything in this record, really, because the appellants were charged not with deceptive advertising or not with poor quality of services or anything else; they were charged with advertising.
And the findings all along the way simply said they advertised, they are disciplined.

So we are really simply anticipating arguments the State might make for a constitutional rule justifying this kind of an overbroad total ban, and we submit that its overbreadth itself is enough to strike it down.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Canby, you said a moment ago that you thought perhaps there was some difference in the protection accorded to commercial speech than to traditional political speech.
Do you think the doctrine of overbreadth would apply with all its force in the area of commercial speech the way it does with ideological or political speech?

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: I think that it would, because largely when you say "all its force", perhaps there are instances when it would not.

It seems to me when it is just speech -- in other words, the publication of something in the paper -- overbreadth is appropriate, and indeed a great part of the opinion in Bigelow against Virginia was that overbreadth when it is the pure transmission of a message is quite appropriate an approach here, even though it is strong medicine.
This ban, for instance, does not permit the kind of thing that the ABA has said is permissible, like setting up a display box in the classified pages giving the fee for initial consultation.
The ABA has permitted this in its amendments, which are in the Appendix at 449, and the morning press tells me the Michigan Court has adapted this; but Arizona does not.
It seems to me that is an example of overbreadth.
But we would also be quite content, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, to stand on the ad here.

We think that this ad is protected, and we are very anxious to establish that the advertisement of a fee for a particular service, which is, in fact, held to and performed competently, is not deceptive and, in fact, it is very helpful to the consumer to have that information.

The arguments that professionalism is simply inconsistent with advertising might have been easily accepted several years ago, but there simply is too much advertising done now, or there are too many organizations which are willing to endorse it, to entertain the idea that some other professions simply cannot operate with advertising.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, the trend, though, in the legal profession has been just in the opposite direction, hasn't it?

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: The one-century trend certainly has.
There was advertising --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, that is a hundred years ago.
Lawyers did advertise, didn't they?

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Routinely or standard operating procedure?

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, and in fact the first Code of Ethics of any Bar Association in this country, the Alabama Bar in the 1880s, specifically stated that newspaper advertisements were proper, and it was subsequently after the American Bar Association was organized after the turn of the century they began to restrict this.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Does Arizona have an integrated Bar?

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: It does, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Every lawyer is a member of the Bar.

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.
It is interesting that even the seed of the profession seems to be changing, too.
The Monopolies Commission in England has recommended that solicitors be permitted to advertise, and action is being taken on that recommendation.
The Governors of the D.C. Bar Association here in the District of Columbia have recommended advertising which would permit price advertising by individual attorneys.
That has not yet… in fact, it was just recently submitted to the District of Columbia courts; there has been no action on that.
In summary of the First Amendment problems, I think that all of the arguments of the State really depend on the public's not knowing something.
And this runs afoul of the Virginia State Board of Pharmacy strictures that protecting the public by keeping it in ignorance really is not the way of the First Amendment.
The question, it seems to me, that has to be asked in this case is, what is it in this ad that the consumers or the public really ought not to know?
Apparently it would be all right to put it in a written list, and there is evidence in the record that when people telephone attorneys, the attorneys, “set fees" for things like uncontested divorces.
Well, if that can be told to a person when he calls, what is it about the advertisement that means that the public should not generally be told that without having to call and compare?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Would you think it would advance professionalism if your clients, having put the ad which they used, then another group of lawyers would publish an ad 10% less?

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: I think it would if they published an ad stating the fees.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: It would advance professionalism?

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: I think it would, because I think the greatest duty of the profession is to extend legal services to the public that does not have it and that legal services have regularly been available to a very restricted portion of the population.
And I think that this kind of thing would tend, for one thing -- and there is economic expert testimony on this -- this kind of advertising will tend to drive prices of legal services down.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Is there a reproduction of the ad as it appeared in the paper someplace?

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: At Page 409 in the Appendix, Mr. Justice.
I would like to say a few words here about the antitrust portion of this argument.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Before you do that, Mr. Canby, would you tell us which issue you think we should decide first of the two?
The Government has a different view than the litigants, apparently.

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: Well, the normal rule, I suppose, of this Court is that you decide statutory grounds and avoid constitutional decisions when possible.
I think that in this case, the First Amendment argument is admittedly simpler.
And there certainly are occasions when this Court has decided a constitutional argument where there is a clear violation of the constitution without entering the statutory ground.
Incidentally, in the other drug-price case, Terry v. the State Board of Pharmacy out in California, the Three-Judge Court did just that.

There were both First Amendment and antitrust grounds set forth in that case; they decided the First Amendment ground -- this was before the Virginia State Board of Pharmacy case was decided here -- and then they said, "We simply won't reach the antitrust issues".
The antitrust issues in this case, of course, revolve primarily around the State action, so-called exemption of Parker v. Brown.

And here, the Justice Department, whose support we welcome on the First Amendment, takes leave of us and takes this position with some reluctance and I can understand their reluctance, because in the record in this case, for instance, other professions testified as to their practices.
The accountants, for instance, had a rule against competitive bidding.
It was a rule of their national association, and it became a rule of their state association, and it became a rule of the State Board of Accountancy in Arizona: no competitive bidding.
This was abandoned at the national level, according to the record, under threat of Justice Department action.
It was abandoned at the State level by the State Board when our State Attorney General wrote an opinion to the Board that it violated State and Federal antitrust laws.
Other kinds of restraints are common.
The architects, for instance, who permit solicitation, permit solicitation, but not price competition.
Well, these are restraints of trade, and they are restraints of trade that regulated professions can easily get incorporated into rules of the profession.
And the restraint is great, as it is in this case.
The Parker v. Brown, of course, dealt with an anticompetitive raise and marketing scheme that was imposed by legislative command of the State.

The evolution of Parker into which we believe this case can be fit is that announced in Cantor v. Detroit Edison, where this Court said the practice of furnishing free light bulbs by a regulated utility violated the antitrust laws, even though it was incorporated in a tariff which had been approved by the State Utilities Commission, and the utility was not free under State law to deviate from that practice.
Now, in Cantor, the Cantor case, of course, is distinguishable, in that the State was not the one which was doing the enforcing; it was a suit against a private utility.

Here, we are taking the next step basically and trying to prevent the enforcement of a restrictive trade practice which the State has approved by adopting this rule, which was clearly originated by the ABA, both its predecessor and the present one, and adopting it into a rule of the State Supreme Court.

The language which, it seems to me, the Government is overlooking in Cantor is that which deals with the fact -- and this was dealt with also in Goldfarb -- that whether or not the State is involved there is a threshold question.
And if the State is not involved, as this Court really did not feel it was in Goldfarb, then there is no immunity.
But that is the threshold question.
Of course, the State is involved here, the court is enforcing this.
Well, then, what question comes after the threshold, and that is, is this rule really necessary to make the regulatory system work?
How badly does it interfere with the system of free competition that the Sherman Act has mandated?
And what interests of the State make this rule necessary, and what ones do not?

And in this case, we submit that the same interests which we find to be weak when they are measured as a First Amendment part of the State’s balance are equally weak when they are measured in the antitrust balance.
There is no question here, of course, that this is a restraint, and that is the restraint of price advertising affects the price structure, a more or less classic antitrust restraint.
The fact that the State is enforcing it is not the whole answer.
For instance, the State was enforcing its own rule basically, or at least a State command was involved, in the Schwegman case.
The Schwegman case was an attempt basically to invalidate the state non-signer law under the fair-trade acts, and it succeeded.

The State command was invalid, because it conflicted with the command of the Sherman Act; in other words, that fair-trade practice did not fall within an exemption to the Sherman Act that Congress had created.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, have the restrictions, however, originated with the State or with the Bar?

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: The restrictions here originated with the American Bar Association.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, they may have; but the Bar has not any choice any more, has it?

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: They have not, but I would submit neither did the utility in Cantor.
They no longer had a choice.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, yeah; but they did originally.
They could have filed a new tariff.

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: That is true.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, the Bar cannot here file some new rules with the Supreme Court and automatically have to up one of these rules.

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: It certainly would not be automatic.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, then it is State-prescribed, isn't it?

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: It is State-commanded, that is correct.
But it --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: In the Cantor case, once you filed, you had to do what you said you were going to do.

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: That is true.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But you had to live up to your own tariff.

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: I believe, though, that those tariffs --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But they could have discontinued the tariff.

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: I believe that technically, that has to be approved by the --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: They cannot send a notice to the Supreme Court here and say, “By the way, we are now discontinuing the rules you published”.

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: No, they certainly cannot.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, what would be left of Parker if you --

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: Well, there would be less left of Parker.
I think my --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But what would be left of Parker?

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: Well, in the first place, where there is a high State interest -- and I think the best example, I suppose, of what would be left of Parker is the natural monopoly which public utilities are an example of -- if the State wants to regulate the price structure of attorneys, then fine.

I think that if they decide, for instance, either to hire the lawyers or to put the lawyers under the State Corporation Commission and regulate their rates, then there is a very considerable argument that the State has substituted interests which restrain the excesses of monopoly for those which otherwise are provided by the Sherman Act.
Here, of course, the State command frees lawyers from a certain kind of price competition; but it does not exert any real pressure on the lawyers to keep their rates down.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, would you be making the same argument if, say, the Legislature of Colorado suddenly rears back and passes a law that says there shall be no price advertising or any other kind of advertising by lawyers, and the lawyers live up to it as a group?

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: I think that would violate the Sherman Act; but I must say that that is a much weaker case, because there, at least the political arm of the State has presumably considered the --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, even if Parker was not available, how would you prove a Sherman Act violation if lawyers just obeyed that law?
So they do not agree to anything; they just live up to the rule.

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: That is the importance, it seems to me, of the fact that there is more than a mere request by the Bar in this case to pass this rule.
This rule is --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That makes your Sherman Act case weaker, doesn't it?
No.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Canby, if instead of a defense you were bringing an antitrust action, who would you name as defendants in this case?

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: If I were bringing an antitrust action, I imagine that I would bring it against the State Bar.
But it seems to me it is a different --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You would bring it against the State Bar?

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: It is a very different question.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Would the State Bare and Supreme Court rule remain in effect?

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: The State Bar might well be exempted as a matter of fairness from damages if it had no option but to obey the law.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But supposing you won your case against the State Bar, and the Supreme Court of Arizona said “We don't care what happened to that litigation.
We still have this Rule.
We are going to disbar people who do not follow our Rule”.
Wouldn't you have to name the members of the Supreme Court in order to prevail?

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: Well, perhaps, or at least if enforcement was attempted, then to defend on that ground, and it seems to me if the Michigan Utilities Commission the day after the Cantor decision came down said, “All right, now, we are holding the utility to its tariff, because our State law says you have to be held to it”, then I think the utility would have a defense against that.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: The utility have a defense that the tariff it proposed itself was unlawful?

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: It seems to me an intervening decision of this Court would provide that.

Otherwise, of course, this Court and the Utilities Commission will be commanding inconsistent conduct, and I would suggest that the Supremacy Clause here simply dictates that the Federal command prevail, if I answered Mr. Justice White’s question.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, don't be too quick to bring suit.

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: No, right, I will not.
In summary, I will simply say that in our view, both the antitrust laws and the First Amendment apply, and a balancing test applies.
The balance here in favor of public information of this kind is tremendous, and the State’s interests to the contrary are not.
The decision should be reversed.
I reserve any remaining time for rebuttal.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Very well, Mr. Canby.
Mr. Friedman?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Friedman, before you commence, let me share with you at least my primary concern of this case.

I think all lawyers agree that the problem being discussed here today is a very serious one, important for the public and the profession, and the delivery of legal services in our country obviously is defective.
The problem that I think concerns all of us on this bench and at the Bar is what to do about it.
Lawyers have advertised to some extent always.
Anybody who knows about Martindale can find out where lawyers went to school, how old they are and, until recently at least, who their clients were.
They can also find in what areas of specialization lawyers are professed to be competent in their practice.
I hope you will have time to address not just the barebones issue of whether or not there can be any advertising, I do not perceive that as the basic issue in this case.
The question is what limits rationally, fairly, constitutionally may be imposed; who imposes those limits, and how are they enforced?
These are the broader contours of the problem.
We could decide this case and may very well do it in a very narrow way, but that would not advance the resolution of the fundamental problem.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Well, let me address myself directly to that question, Mr. Justice Powell.
I think we start with the basic issue that has been suggested in this case is a narrow one, whether there can be an absolute ban on all advertising.

And the position of the United States is that this absolute ban imposed by the State of Arizona goes beyond the permissible limits of the First Amendment; it is inconsistent with the First Amendment because of the strong interest in members of the public in getting information about legal services, both their availability and their cost.

Now, we also, of course, recognize there is a very strong interest in ensuring high ethical standards at the Bar, as this Court has indicated, both because of the critical role that lawyers play in the administration of justice and their role as officers of the court.
Obviously, lawyers do not stand in exactly the same position as the average merchant who is selling a standardized product.
He is selling a special service.

But we think that the First Amendment requires that any restraints that the State does impose upon the dissemination of information by lawyers to the public as potential clients cannot go beyond what is necessary adequately to protect the State’s interests.
Now, that ultimate balancing in First Amendment cases has to be done by the courts.
Of course, the State has the power to prevent misleading and deceptive, false advertising by lawyers; and the State has a broader authority than that.

There may be many things that a merchant can do that it is not proper for a lawyer to do, because it is important to this country that the people of this country have a high regard for the legal profession because of its critical role in the administration of justice.
But we do not think that because of the importance that the lawyers play in the legal system and in the operation of our country that this means the Bar can say there can be no advertising at all.
We do not think the Bar can go that far.
Now, there are problems, of course, of policing these things.
And I might just add in passing that we have indicated in our brief that there are some recent indications of suggestions of what would be permissible.
We are not espousing any of these.
All that we cite these for is to point out that the problem is not to us an all-or-nothing problem.
It is not either there can be no advertising or that there is got to be enormous discretion.
There have to be some limitations.
Now, one of the problems --

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: May I interrupt you just a minute right there?
I think we start from the premise that some advertising already is permitted.
So the total ban issue as I perceive it is not here.
We do have an extent of the ban under the Arizona Rule.
But Mr. Canby stated quite explicitly that he thought the First Amendment entitled lawyers to talk about the quality of their services.
What is the Government’s position on that?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Well, that, it seems to me again, would depend on what is said.
If statements with respect to the quality of services are misleading, the State can prohibit them.
I do not think a lawyer could publish an ad saying, “Come to me, I am a better lawyer than anyone else in town”.
It seems to me that is not the kind of statement, although permissible to a merchant, that a lawyer could properly state.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Suppose in this case, a competing lawyer had published an ad saying, “The partners in this clinic have been practicing divorce law on a part-time basis for four years.
I am a specialist in divorce law.
I have been practicing it for 20 years.
My fees are the same".
Is that all right?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: I would think the derogatory thing would present problems to me.
I would think that it would be permissible if the ad stated merely that “If you need a divorce, we have been practicing divorce law for 20 years”.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: What is derogatory about that comparative statement if it is true?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Well, it seems to me it is derogatory, Mr. Chief Justice, because the suggestion is somehow that we are better than they are, and it is the negative suggestion against them.
It seems to me this gets into the area where I think there may be problems with respect to what is permissible.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, does the First Amendment prohibit derogatory communication?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: No, no.
It is not the First Amendment prohibits derogatory communications, Mr. Justice.

We think it is that the First Amendment does permit lawyers to get to the public their position that they are available to the public and indicating what their services are and what they will charge for them.
Now --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, what about simply saying, “Anything you can do, I can do better”?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: I do not think that would be permissible, Mr. Justice.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Why?

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Why not?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: If the First Amendment compels the inclusion that you suggest, then where do these limits come from, then?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: I think the limits come --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: They certainly do not come from the First Amendment.
Where do they come from?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: No, the limits come, I think, Mr. Justice, from the role of the lawyers and the differences, the kind of differences that exist with respect to what is an appropriate kind of regulation of the legal profession.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Since when under the First Amendment is a governmental body, be it judicial or executive or legislative, allowed to regulate speech?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Well, it is not regulating speech in that sense.
What it is saying is that there are certain kinds of speech and certain things done by lawyers are not consistent with the standards that we accept of lawyers.

If I may give a simple example, I suppose there is no question under the First Amendment that a merchant can put at the most far-reaching and the most sweeping claims for his stuff: “Come to our store, the best store in town.
Don't patronize anyone else,” that kind of thing.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: There has been no question for something less than a year.
A year ago, there would have been a great question whether a merchant had any First Amendment right at all to do that.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: That, I think, now has to be accepted that there is a First Amendment protection to commercial speech.

But the fact that there is a commercial-speech protection under the First Amendment does not necessarily mean, as this Court itself has suggested in those cases, that when you are dealing with numbers of the professions that necessarily there has to be the same sweep to the protection they have as is to be given to the common garden variety of commercial speech; that is, the things that can be said about advertising prescription drugs are not necessarily the same things that can be said when a lawyer brings his message to the public.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Quite obviously.
But I understand this is a court that decides questions of Federal Constitutional or statutory law.
The issue here is whether or not the First Amendment of the United States Constitution requires Arizona to do something else, and it did.
And if it does, then it requires Arizona to allow lawyers to advertise.
But, now, where do all these limitations come from in the Federal law, Constitutional or statutory?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Well, I think it comes in, Mr. Justice, in the balancing process, in determining just how far the State can go in restraint.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You think it is up to us to say that?
Where does our power come from?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Well, in the first instance, it has to be the State that makes the judgment, and the State in this case has not made any judgment other than the judgment that there shall be no advertising at all by lawyers in the State of Arizona, and that is what we think is bad, this absolute ban.
Now, if the Court agrees with us that the absolute ban is bad, that does not mean that you have to go all the way and say that there can be absolutely no limits at all.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Arizona, as my brother Powell has pointed out, does not really mean what it has said, does it?
It does not ban the circulation of Martindale-Hubbell in the State of Arizona.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: No, but what they are really talking about, it seems to me, is advertising directly to the public.
Martindale-Hubbell is basically, I think, directed to members of the Bar.

I think what Arizona does do is bar any advertising by lawyers to the public, anything that the lawyers do that gets to the public, the lawyer’s position as announcing the availability of their services and indicating the costs at which they will furnish them.
I think --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What principle of the Federal Constitution says that Arizona cannot do what it did, but another state could prohibit derogatory advertisement by one lawyer about another?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: I would think so.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, where does that come from, Mr. Friedman?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Where does it come from?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: But I think it comes from the recognition that the First Amendment protection given to commercial advertising by lawyers does not necessarily have the full force and effect as the First Amendment protection given to commercial advertising by merchants, that it is protected.
It is protected by the First Amendment, but the scope of the protection is not as sweeping as the protection given to the more traditional kinds of commercial speech.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Friedman, are you not suggesting a distinction based squarely on the content of the advertising, the content of the speech?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Yes, I think I am, Mr. Justice, and I think the Court last year in the American Mini Theatres' case recognized that there may be situations in which you can refer to the content of the speech.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Would you agree that your position must fail unless the Court is willing to state that the content may be the basis for differentiating between kinds of protected speech and unprotected speech?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Well, no, Mr. Justice.

There are situations, it seems to me, very clearly where the content of the speech does control the measure to which it can be regulated, and in the field of commercial advertising, the Court pointed out last year that while there was a First Amendment right to distribute and announce the prices at which prescription drugs were being sold, it did not follow from that that there was a First Amendment right to make false and misleading statements.
So it seems to me the Court does look to see what the content is.
If it is false and misleading, certainly the maker of these statements cannot claim that it is constitutionally protected.
I think --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But it seems to me you are taking two different positions.
One time, you and Mr. Canby both kept saying you can prohibit false and misleading.
But Mr. Justice Rehnquist asked you about derogatory.
It can be truthfully derogatory.
So your only line surely is not the false-and-misleading line, is it?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: No, it goes somewhat beyond that.
I do not know precisely at what point the line has to be drawn.
That, it seems to me, is a line that in the first instance has to be drawn by the State, because the State has the broad regulatory authority over the legal profession.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You gave an example earlier about a merchant, something to the effect of saying he is the best in town or something like that.
Are you suggesting that that could be prohibited?
For example, could the State say that a lawyer may not advertise that his fees are very reasonable, which is precisely what this person did.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Well, this person merely stated reasonable fees.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: No, very reasonable.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Very reasonable fees, very reasonable fees.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Is that permissible under your view?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: I would think that kind of a statement is permissible.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: So, some statement of opinion --

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Some statement, yes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: -- other than the mere fact.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Some statement.
But, again, I think it has to take into account the whole matrix of the whole relationship of the Bar to the public.
That is, that are certain things, it seems to me, that the State fairly can conclude are not properly to be done by members of the Bar that could be done by nonprofessionals.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And one of them may be to advertise at all, if what you say is correct.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: That is where we disagree, of course.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, then, where do these limitations come from?
They either have a First Amendment right to do this short of defrauding people or being deceptive or false, or they do not.
Where in the Constitution or the Federal law, the Federal Constitution or any federal statute, do these limitations come from?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: I think these limitations derive, Mr. Justice, from the nature of the legal profession and from the fact that traditionally in evaluating First Amendment rights there has to be this balancing test, and when you consider a limitation on all advertising as distinguished from the limitation on certain types of advertising, it seems to me the State’s interest in restricting certain forms of advertising may be much, much greater than the State’s interest in --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It seems to me that what you are proposing is a considerably more arbitrary standard than the one that Arizona has adapted.
Once it has been recognized that there is a First Amendment right to speak or to write, where anywhere has there ever been found any permissible limitation upon it so long as it is true?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: But I think, Mr. Justice, I have suggested --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Where?
I would like you an answer to that question.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Well, let me see if I can answer it this way, that in determining what the First Amendment right is, when we say there is a First Amendment right to advertise, that does not mean a First Amendment right to advertise any conceivable thing.
And I --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Is there not a First Amendment right to speak the truth?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: No, there is.
There is a First Amendment right, of course, to speak the truth.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: All right.

Then how can you have any limitations if you are correct about the First Amendment referring this, where does any limitation come from that allows any governmental agency, Executive, Legislative or Judicial, to impose any limitations on lawyers’ rights to speak the truth when they advertise, including saying, "I have been practicing divorce law for 20 years and am the most experienced divorce lawyer in this community"?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Well, I think the latter, it seems to me, I think they could say.
I think they could say the latter.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And here are my fees, and they are no higher lawyer than any lawyer's in town.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: I think, up to that point, yes; up to that point, yes.
But at some point, it seems to me they may go beyond this, because at some point they are likely to say things that seemingly are wholly factual, but in fact may not be that factual.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, let us try balancing on that score.
You mentioned the balancing process.

Suppose this lawyer or office has advertised wills for $25, and then they put along with the supermarket ads an ad of their own saying, “$25 wills, Saturday only: $14.95”? Do you think they could do that?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: I would think if they were prepared for any client who came in on Saturday to draw a will for $14.95, although $ 25 is the regular price, they could state that.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But does anybody know what a $25 will is in the first place?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Well, there may be something deceptive if, in fact, they never draw wills for $25; but if they say “a simple will, $25” and in fact they are drawing wills for people for $25, it seems to me they could state that.

And I think they could also state that on Saturdays, a special for the man who is working five days a week and cannot come to see us during the week, $14.95, I think they could say that as long as it is truthful.
If, in fact, when people came in for their $25 wills or their $14.95 wills, they quickly told them, “Well, your will is much more complicated.
It is going to cost you $150”, that would seem to be misleading in the classical, traditional sense.
But I do not think they can be stopped for telling the truth.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That is just a bait-and-switch trick.
We are not talking about that.
We are talking about… well, you can go ahead.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: If I may, Mr. Chief Justice and members of the Court, I would just like very briefly to speak about the Parker v. Brown point, which has been discussed briefly here.

It seems to us that what the cases in this Court starting with Parker v. Brown and going through Cantor have established is one fundamental principle, that if the action challenges a violation of the antitrust laws is, in fact, action of the State or compelled by the State, it is a State action not subject to the strictures of the antitrust laws.

Now, in this case, unlike the Virginia case where all that happened with regard to the fee schedules was that the State approved them or suggested them or authorized them, here, the State commands it.

It is a rule of the State Supreme Court of Arizona, and if I may just complete this, Mr. Chief Justice, the State Supreme Court is the one that exercises the function of the State of Arizona in dealing with lawyer discipline.
This is not a case where the Bar Association suggests something and the State Supreme Court says, “If you want to do it, go ahead and do it.”
Here, as has been brought out, it is the State Supreme Court, the final arbiter on these matters, that has ordered the lawyers in Arizona not to advertise.
It is the State Supreme Court that has disciplined these lawyers for advertising.

The State is speaking in this matter through the only agency by which it functions with respect to disciplining of lawyers and that, it seems to us, is State action under any standard of the term and is therefore not a violation of the Sherman Act.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Friedman.
Mr. Frank, we will not ask you to go for a minute-and-a-half.
We will let you begin at 1:00.

turn.speaker: john_p_frank
turn.label: Mr. John P. Frank
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Frank?

turn.speaker: john_p_frank
turn.label: Mr. John P. Frank
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.
From Mr. Canby and the amici and the Government, I draw a certain common syllogism.
The major premise is that not enough people receive legal services.
The minor premise is that solicitation by advertising will greatly aid the deprived.
The conclusion is that the First Amendment to the Federal Constitution requires that advertising be permitted.

In response to this, my own single greatest obligation from all of the sources on which we have drawn is to Mr. Frederick Ballard of the Bar of this city, who almost, Mr. Justice Powell, in response to your comment, in making a speech of his own on this subject directed me to a singularly opposite aphorism by H.L. Mencken, which I repeat: "For every serious problem, there is a solution which is simple, direct and wrong."

While we acknowledge the sincerity of those who with Biblical fervor contemplate the vision of striking the rock and having a stream of pure water come out to slightly first of the multitude, we frankly find it astonishing that they can be so blind to the cataclysmic flood which they seek to unleash.

What you are asked to believe is that if you give your permission, the nation will be dotted with noble souls who will, by advertising, communicate to those otherwise unaware their desire to perform worthwhile and needed service at very low costs.
This frankly visionary speculation overlooks the human experience, which tells us that you would be unleashing quite a different flood.
The plain truth of the matter is that advertising law business leads to incompetence, at best.
In the experience of the Patent Office, which tried it and after full hearings concluded in formal opinion that this was exactly true, is good documentation.
But to put it bluntly, it leads to lying, cheating and swindling at its worst.
We do not have to guess about this; we know.
We know because, as Justice Stewart reminded us this morning, there was no limitation on advertising in the 19th Century, and what I am talking about is exactly what happened.

The only notes we have of an oral argument that was ever made by Abraham Lincoln at the trial court involved a case of the widow of a Revolutionary War veteran who was represented by what was then called a claims agent, who was permitted to get his business by solicitation, and he was doing what within our own time would be regarded as legal work.
Lincoln took the widow’s case without charge to try to recover some of what that agent had kept.
And perhaps some of you have seen the notes of that argument and can imagine the immense force of the underlying phrase at the end of it, which says, “Skin the defendant”.
It is not any wonder that Lincoln told the law students, “Never stir up litigation.
A worse man can scarcely be found than one who does this.
A moral tone ought to be infused into the profession which would drive such men out of it”.
Now, I want to make very clear that for those of us who oppose a ban on solicitation, we do not regard this as the pieties of the dead to which we are somehow paying lip service.
The other side says in its brief that what a different era called runners and cappers are quite anachronisms which do not need to concern us any more.
We do not see it that way.

We say that the lawyer who directly or true his intermediary goes to the hospital to line up the injured to sue is unworthy of the profession and, in Mr. Lincoln’s phrase, “ought to be driven out of it”.

Mr. Canby says that he would like to seek controls on that score, but his client said at trial in response to the question: “Do you believe you have the same First Amendment right to go to the hospital or give your cards at the scene of the accident?” was, after some waffling, "I think that it may well be true that if tested, a lawyer has a constitutional right to engage in that solicitation".

No lawyer of integrity -- I put it this strongly -- no lawyer of integrity can read our recitation of what actually happens with actual solicitation -- we took the cases from California as an example -- frankly without his stomach turning.

Even when our guard is all the way up, there are persons who solicit the widow and the orphan and the sick to bring actions which are, first and foremost, intended to line the pockets of those who represent them.
We say that this is absolutely bad business.

We take as our contemporary champion Chief Justice Roger Traynor, who wisely said, speaking of the very persons that our friends here wish to help, the persons who are inexperienced, who do not know about legal council, who are having their first run up.

What Chief Justice Traynor said was, “Clients who need legal assistance only rarely, and are therefore inexperienced in selecting counsel, may be induced by advertisement to select unsuitable counsel, with consequent injury not only to themselves, but to the reputation to the Bar as a whole".
Now, the argument which you heard this morning, the counterargument is that all these evils can be avoided by permitting only honest advertising and by controlling the deceptive.
If there is one element of sanctimonious pap in this whole case, that is it.
The argument fails for three reasons: first, advertising to be gravely undesirable does not have to be misleading.
There were examples mentioned this morning.

Exuberant puffing of the raps beaten here or the six $100,000 verdicts last year may be true without being very desirable; second, the hustle is peculiarly likely to push people where they should not go when there is no real likelihood that they can appraise their own situation.

This is a matter to which I want to return; the third, and the main point I would develop now, the whole talk of controlling misleading advertising by criminal or regulatory sanctions is itself the biggest hoax, the biggest misleading of all.

The plain truth is -- and I direct myself, Justice Marshall, to the exchange you had about, are we talking only about absolute control -- what we are talking about is a prohibition of legal advertising in newspapers, in this case by people who are trying to make money out of them, and that is prohibited in our state.
And I point this out, that in all of the briefs you have had -- Mr. Canby, the Government and the rest of them -- no one has ever yet told you how these controls are supposed to function.
No one gives you more than an amenable invocation of honesty.
The granddaddy of all false professional advertising, of course, is medicine.
The spellbinding patent-medicine vendor with his snake-oil cures is a 19th Century legend, which we allow to become amusing because it is so remote.

We have created a Food and Drug Administration which works in a kind of a way, sluggishly and expensively, to control the abuses of the national drug concerns, few in number, which manufacture the bulk of the products you spoke about in the prescription-drug case.
But the only protection the public gets from misleading advertising at the grassroots level is the ethical system of the doctors themselves.

I level a direct challenge to our adversaries here: if you allow a general pattern of advertising -- and what you do here for lawyers you are going to do for accountants and for doctors; they are in the same pot -- if you allow this, just exactly who is going to look at the hundreds of thousands of ads which may come out?
Who is to appraise whether they are misleading?
Who is to do anything about it?
The institutions do not exist.
There is no procedure, no structure.
All we are doing is opening the gate and saying, “Let her come”.
Now, Justice Rehnquist, you raised in colloquy the argument of overbreadth, which Justice Canby talked about, the argument that the ban is too broad.

Chief Justice Hughes, than whom no more towering debatteur of free speech ever sat here, told us in a similar case that society did not need to pick and choose which professional ads are invidious and which are not.
This Court in the recent Mini Theatres' case observed that in commercial speech, the content of a particular advertisement may determine the extent of its protection.
Chief Justice Hughes had something to say about content.
He told us that professional advertising is what it is: inherently misleading.
He expressly rejected the concept that control of professional-service advertising must be as narrow as possible to fit only precise abuses.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: What is inherently misleading about the ad in this case on Page 409?

turn.speaker: john_p_frank
turn.label: Mr. John P. Frank
turn.text: This is a good example, Mr. Justice Blackmun.
I would like to be specific about it.

The Supreme Court of Arizona pointed out instances in which even this ad, which is a little squib of an ad meant to be a test case and they make it as perfect as they can; so they tell us first of all that this was a legal clinic, and they somehow imply that there is something virtue or cheaper about it, virtuous or inexpensive.
But when we cross-examine them on the stand, there is no conception of what a legal clinic is; it is a meaningless term, simply a kind of an invocation of nothingness.
More than that, they are offering particularly economical services, particularly beneficial prices.
Take, for example, the one of their consent divorces.
They have also told us on this record that they charge $40 an hour for their time.
They have told us on this record that their divorces take between an hour-and-a-half and three hours' maximum.
And it is no wonder that the Supreme Court of Arizona observed that this is outright misleading on its face, this indication of some great bargain for these so-called consent divorces.
The one on which there is the greatest tone of misleading, a matter to which I may come back, is to talk about name changes, and that also was picked up by the Supreme Court below.
The truth of the matter is that anybody in our town who wants to can go and get his name changed for nothing, and you do not need legal services for this.
So the question of whether somehow this is a great benefaction to mankind is highly doubtful.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What is it precisely that you feel is misleading about the divorce and $175 plus $20 court costs?

turn.speaker: john_p_frank
turn.label: Mr. John P. Frank
turn.text: The point that is misleading is the suggestion that somehow this is some kind of a grand public-service bargain.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, where do you get that out of the ad?
Are you saying that that is not a very reasonable fee?

turn.speaker: john_p_frank
turn.label: Mr. John P. Frank
turn.text: I am saying that given the standards of these people, who are purporting to be entitled to special dispensation because they are being so generous to the lower middle class, that the answer is, no, it is not.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But that is not in the ad, is it?

turn.speaker: john_p_frank
turn.label: Mr. John P. Frank
turn.text: It is when you connect it with the notion of the legal clinic and the special service and that somehow we are prized and special.
I agree, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, that I cannot make this ad into a devastating falsehood; it is not, it is marginal.
The point that I want to make is that it is --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: That is my initial question.

turn.speaker: john_p_frank
turn.label: Mr. John P. Frank
turn.text: Yes.
It is, and I am answering it as hard and as solid as I know how.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: We need to get there, Mr. Frank.

turn.speaker: john_p_frank
turn.label: Mr. John P. Frank
turn.text: All right.

What I am saying, Mr. Justice Blackmun, is that the three items which we have suggested in our brief which we suggest are at least marginally misleading are, number one, the suggestion that there is something called a legal clinic.
On the record, it is apparent that this is an empty term, which somehow imputes special value and special economy.

On examination as to what the legal clinic is -- and there is a full-scale record before you showing it -- it turns out that what a legal clinic does is what every office in Phoenix does: that they use paralegals, that they have forms and so on.

Secondly, the Supreme Court below broadly suggested, and I think correctly, that the suggestion that this is somehow a great bargain price for divorces is misleading, especially measured by their own hourly rate and the time that it takes for them to do it.
And finally --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: They do not even say that it is a bargain; they just say it is reasonable.

turn.speaker: john_p_frank
turn.label: Mr. John P. Frank
turn.text: They say it is reasonable; but I think, Mr. Justice White --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Better you stay close to that.

turn.speaker: john_p_frank
turn.label: Mr. John P. Frank
turn.text: I am sorry, thank you.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: …and watch your embarrass-able words before you say them.

turn.speaker: john_p_frank
turn.label: Mr. John P. Frank
turn.text: All right, posterity will not be let down.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Good.

turn.speaker: john_p_frank
turn.label: Mr. John P. Frank
turn.text: Mr. Justice White, I think that it is fair to say that the whole tone of this advertisement, the whole tone of the brief, is that somehow we are doing something very special for the community, we are being just great folks, and we are giving you wonderful bargains.

Now, on the matter, if I may conclude, as to the name change and then pick that up, sir, on the name-change point, what the attorney said when he was examined on the stand about the fact that you can get those for nothing, you do not need to pay $95, is, "I feel under no obligation to tell people that they can get services cheaper somewhere else".
I submit that the tone of the thing is not quite what is being presented to you here today of some great virtue and economy.
Mr. Justice Stevens?

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Frank, what is the prevailing fee in this community for an uncontested divorce?

turn.speaker: john_p_frank
turn.label: Mr. John P. Frank
