turn.text: Let me answer by saying first that the difficulty arises because the term "uncontested divorce" is a sliding term.
I would say uncontested divorce could run, depending upon how uncontested they really are, anywhere from around $150 to around $300.
I have handled them myself for anything in that whole zone in the course of the years from time to time.
This is a low price, but it is not some spectacular bargain.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Judged by the standards of the community rather than their own hourly charge, it is a reasonable fee, is it not?

turn.speaker: john_p_frank
turn.label: Mr. John P. Frank
turn.text: It is certainly a moderate fee.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Then what is so misleading about the rest of it?

turn.speaker: john_p_frank
turn.label: Mr. John P. Frank
turn.text: Well, again, I come back to the fact -- and this is simply the best I can do with it, Mr. Justice Stevens -- that I think that even in this simple ad they are trying to suggest some extra-special, and there is not anything that extra-special here.

In the Williamson and Lee Optical case, this Court in a unanimous opinion by Justice Douglas, which followed Chief Justice Hughes’ opinions in sum, are expressed in dealing with advertising which related to health said that the legislature was entitled to conclude that advertising could be limited or even abolished in the public interest.

And the Court said, “We see no constitutional reason why a State may not treat all who deal with the human eye as members of a profession who should use no merchandising methods for obtaining customers”.

We submit that it is plain false logic for the other side to say that the Hughes opinion or the Cardozo opinion that preceded it or the Douglas opinion that followed it somehow are all immaterial, because they did not use the precise words “free speech”.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, Mr. Frank, what if the United Mine Workers or the United Transportation Union published this same ad, and at the bottom it said the United Mine Workers Legal Clinic and then, under it, it gave the name of the lawyers, otherwise published the same ad, and they just circulated it in their union newspaper, published it in their union newspaper to all of their members or to anybody else who wanted to buy it.

turn.speaker: john_p_frank
turn.label: Mr. John P. Frank
turn.text: Mr. Justice White, you have, in effect, raised the question of a series of cases which have come up here which have upheld group legal services and permitted effective advertising communication through them; and the answer is that that would not be a violation in the State of Arizona, either.
This talk that you have been given today suggests that somehow Arizona blacks out all kinds of communication.
The fact is that the Rules of the Supreme Court, the one under discussion about newspaper advertising, is a particular rule.
There are others, and there is an express Rule.
And our State has been one of the very first ones to permit institutional advertising for legal services and institutional advertising for groups.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, you are saying that is something that we would not call a group legal service exactly; but the Union… well, your answer is that you would not say that the Arizona Rules would forbid this advertisement published by a union.

turn.speaker: john_p_frank
turn.label: Mr. John P. Frank
turn.text: What I am saying, Your Honor, I am being brief because of the exigency of time; but if you will look at our Rule 2-101, Subparagraph 7, you will find --- I hold it in my hand -- that that kind of thing would be allowed.
What our State sees fit to bar is advertising by individual lawyers in newspapers for the purpose of lining their own pockets.

It expressly permits institutional advertising and benefit of lawyer referral services; it permits advertising for legal-aid organizations; and it would permit certainly the union to tell its people what the services are which are part of the program.

These are matters of very subtle distinction, which our Supreme Court has seen fit to make; but our Supreme Court has not seen fit to allow this kind of advertising of the individual pocket-lining variety.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, do you think the ad that I spoke about published by the union would be constitutionally protected under our cases or not?

turn.speaker: john_p_frank
turn.label: Mr. John P. Frank
turn.text: I am in doubt.
Frankly, I would want to give it tighter thought than I have.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, isn't that a --

turn.speaker: john_p_frank
turn.label: Mr. John P. Frank
turn.text: I do think that it is permitted, at least under the Rules which we have.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I understand that.
I am just wondering what your view was of the constitutional protection or not for an ad as I described.

turn.speaker: john_p_frank
turn.label: Mr. John P. Frank
turn.text: I am in doubt as to whether there is constitutional protection.
I simply, as I say, have not thought it through to my satisfaction.
But that is because I approach it from a different standpoint.
I approach it in terms of who is to make these decisions, a matter to which I will come.
And the contending circumstance here is that the Arizona Supreme Court has determined to do precisely that.
Now, we know that there --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I must admit, Mr. Frank, I am puzzled by your being willing to admit that may be constitutionally protected, but this clearly may not be, and the only distinction is that there is pecuniary gain as a motivation for the person who publishes here.
Is that a constitutional distinction in First Amendment terms?

turn.speaker: john_p_frank
turn.label: Mr. John P. Frank
turn.text: As I say, in respect to the ads which are the ads for the group services, whereas, for example, the union wishes to tell its members --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, precisely this ad by a union.

turn.speaker: john_p_frank
turn.label: Mr. John P. Frank
turn.text: Yes, and the answer is that, for example, you have one of the briefs before you is the brief of the Arizona Credit Union League, and what the Arizona Credit Union League says expressly is, “We don't want to be associated with the argument that Mr. Canby is making”.
What they say is, "It is enough that we are entitled to tell our own members in some effective way about the services which are available to our own members".
And that under the cases, I submit, is permitted and is acceptable.

Where we are drawing a line for a lot of reasons, which go to the nature of professionalism, to which I come and which we reach with determination, is that there is less onslaught and destruction of the profession by allowing groups of that sort to communicate with their members about services available than there is about the kind of thing the Chief Justice talked about, having a lawyer saying “I will give it to you for $19.95 on a hot Saturday afternoon”.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, you would not permit the credit union to do that, would you?

turn.speaker: john_p_frank
turn.label: Mr. John P. Frank
turn.text: All we permit the credit union to do is, first, to arrange for legal services and, second, to tell people that they are there.
I want to make clear that we are no more regressive than our friends about the problem raised by Justice Powell.
Of course we have to do the best we can to extend legal services in the United States; and we have to do a better job than we are doing and we are trying, and that is one of the ways we try.
But the bludgeon of the First Amendment, the main point of the colloquy this morning with Justice Stewart, it is simply not a suitable tool or device for doing it.
Let me turn, if I may, to the concept of commercial speech as being balanced against the community values of the control of that speech.
My own syllogism, unlike the other side's, is, the legal profession is worth preserving.
Its good vastly outweighs its evils; the minor premise is that commercialization is incompatible with professionalism; and the conclusion is, therefore, the profession should avoid commercialization.
Now, I know I have to defend that syllogism against hard attack.
We all know that law offices are big businesses, that they may have billion-dollar or million-dollar clients, they are run with computers and all the rest.
And so the argument may be made that to term them “noncommercial” is sanctimonious humbug.
But my response, developed more fully in my brief than I can here, is very much the response that Plato made to the same argument 2,000 years ago.
Plato, in his dialogue with Thrasymachus in The Republic, makes two points which have some real bearing here.

His first point is that because of the degree of special knowledge involved, the professional on the one hand and his client on the other are, as he saw it, “almost like the ruler and his subject” were the fancy words he used.
In everyday terms, this means that the professional diagnosis, the problem, and he makes his recommendations.
While the client has some choice of rejection or selection of alternative courses of action, he is basically dependent on the advice he receives.

In short, Plato saw a profound difference between buying a pot and obtaining a remedy for a disease, just as there is a profound difference between going to the drugstore and getting a bottle of standard-produced pills and going to the doctor and finding out what one ought to do for his illness.

Now, this, we developed again extensively in the brief before you, is developed by the sociologists as a recognition that this condition still exists, and it puts very serious problems of social control.
The plain truth is that laymen cannot judge a professional performance in many cases.

Indeed, they may not even be able to set the goals for the professional’s work, and this means that the two most common forms of control of work in industrial societies, either bureaucratic supervision or customer judgment, are of only limited applicability to the professions.
At the same time there is a need for social control, and so we come to the ultimate question: who is going to exercise it?
Our adversaries wish it to be exercised by the policemen or a legal equivalent of the Food and Drug Administration.
We want it exercised by the courts, taking such help as they need from the professions.
Now, Plato makes another point which is serious here.
I go into this because if we are talking about professionalism and what this is going to do to the profession, then we need to know what a profession is and what this one is.
Plato says, “Is the physician a healer of the sick or a maker of money?”
And his answer is that no true professional considers his own good in what he describes, but rather the good of his patient, because the true professional is not a mere moneymaker.
And this leads to the related concept of the professional and service, and that has lived with us for 2,000 years.
Roscoe Pound was no high priest of sanctimony, and he gave us a firm reminder of the professional who performs service for little or nothing.
He says, “The spirit of public service in which the profession of law is or ought to be exercised is the prerequisite of sound administration of justice according to law".
This, I submit, is a key difference between commercialization and professionalism.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Mr. Frank, getting back to the present time, if there is a person in Arizona who wants to devolve and he is a perfectly ordinary person, I want to compare him with the well-educated, extremely wealthy person who has an antitrust matter.
He could use Martindale-Hubbell to find out all he wants.

turn.speaker: john_p_frank
turn.label: Mr. John P. Frank
turn.text: That is right.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Now, the poor man who has got $195 to get a divorce, how would he go about finding a lawyer in Arizona?

turn.speaker: john_p_frank
turn.label: Mr. John P. Frank
turn.text: The first thing that he would do, Mr. Justice Marshall, is go to the Legal Aid Society.
And I am able to testify to that, because I personally have served there for a long time and so has my office.
And he would come in there, and he would very possibly get his divorce for nothing.
But if because of breakdown, if because it does not move fast enough to satisfy him and he wants it right now, he will call the lawyer-referral service.
We have in the room today somebody from the ABA’s lawyer-referral service, which is doing the best it can to get names distributed.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: How would the man find the lawyer referral service?

turn.speaker: john_p_frank
turn.label: Mr. John P. Frank
turn.text: He will find the lawyer referral service, because the Bar is able to advertise that this institution exists.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And where is that advertised?

turn.speaker: john_p_frank
turn.label: Mr. John P. Frank
turn.text: It can advertise it in a newspaper or on the radio or in any way it wishes.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Good.
Is it done?

turn.speaker: john_p_frank
turn.label: Mr. John P. Frank
turn.text: It is done, and there are --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Regularly?

turn.speaker: john_p_frank
turn.label: Mr. John P. Frank
turn.text: Yes.
I cannot tell you as to the frequency of the pace.
I can vouch for the fact that serious efforts are made by the Bar to get the word out.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, it did not get to this man.

turn.speaker: john_p_frank
turn.label: Mr. John P. Frank
turn.text: Yeah, if it does not get to this man, then he may have to do what people have traditionally done.
And let me say, it is not much of a problem.
Our town is 50% over the national advertisers in divorces, and people are not having any trouble finding someone to get them for them, not any.
It is just a zero problem in our community.
If anything, we may have too many; they may be finding them too easily, but they are there.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Then they are just wasting their money with this ad.

turn.speaker: john_p_frank
turn.label: Mr. John P. Frank
turn.text: These people think they are making money.
I quoted -- pardon me.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: They are making money from this ad.

turn.speaker: john_p_frank
turn.label: Mr. John P. Frank
turn.text: They may or may not; it depends, obviously, on how many do it.
But they make money, as one of them said, and I quoted him before: “It's not my job to inform a prospective client that he needn't employ a lawyer to handle his work”.
To the true professional and to most of the lawyers in this room, that is shocking; it is turning a law office into a butcher shop.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, Mr. Frank, there was a … at least when I practiced in Phoenix, the County Attorney would do adoptions; but people who could afford adoption would go and have a private lawyer do them, and I am not at all sure that every private attorney who was consulted necessarily said, “Well, you could do just as well with the County Attorney”.

turn.speaker: john_p_frank
turn.label: Mr. John P. Frank
turn.text: I am satisfied, however, that those who sought to be conscientious, as you were when you were in practice and, I must say, I and Mr. Louis as practitioners, do not sell people services that they do not need, and we're mighty scrupulous and invariable about it.
And I hope true professionals are, and I hope that is part of the meaning of professionalism.

I pass over a little of the talk of what the profession is and what we are trying to do with it, simply as a matter of time economy; but I want to drive this home: that part of the business of being a professional is, and we acknowledge it, a kind of a status.
Part of the privilege of that status of being a lawyer and an officer of the court is a meaningful set of duties which go with it.
We are talking about one of them.

More than 100 years ago, the English jurist A.V. Dicey said, "The chief difference between a profession and a trade is that in the case of a profession its member sacrifice a certain amount of individual liberty in order to ensure certain professional objects".
What I am saying is that being a professional means taking your place in a whole network of privileges and duties.

As this Court said in Cohen v. Hurley -- it was overruled later; but on this point, this quote, the majority quoted it and the minority adopted it, and what you said goes to those duties: "It is certainly not beyond the realm of permissible State concern to conclude that too much attention to the business of getting clients may be incompatible with a sufficient devotion to the duties which a lawyer has to the Court".
I have spoken of the direct damage to the public, the kind of thing Chief Justice Traynor was talking about, in letting the snake-oil peddlers loosen the legal profession.
But beyond that, there is the injury which comes to the profession itself and, through it, to the public which I submit benefits from it.
First of all --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Of course, Mr. Frank, I suppose this is arguable in a way.
Didn't this morning some local paper carry an article that the Michigan Court is approving this very thing?

turn.speaker: john_p_frank
turn.label: Mr. John P. Frank
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
And let me go to that this moment and reorder what I have to say and pick that up.
The key point is, one, your comment goes directly to Justice Powell’s first question.
The problem is, who is going to deal with this situation?

The fact is that there are a whole variety of possible solutions, and what I am contending is that it ought to be the Supreme Court or the State Legislatures that can determine in the particular state what is best to do.
There is a whole variety of proposals in the country.
There is the California proposal; there is the District of Columbia proposal; there is what Michigan adopted today.
There is movement on the way to try to deal with the problem of legal services.

And what we face in this case is another example of a wise observation attributed to Mr. Justice Burns when he was a Senator at the time of the Court plan and after there had been a resignation and a replacement, he went to Mr. Roosevelt, runs the legend and says, “Why run for a train after you've caught it?”
The fact of the matter is that all over the country, there is movement; there is in my state.
And these are matters which are commonly and traditionally entrusted to the State Bars and the State courts to solve.
They do not lend to legislation.

The plain truth is that to deal with all those refinements -- you asked the other side about it, the question of this kind, that kind and the other kind -- you cannot do that by constitutional mandate.
Those things take the kinds of regulation that the FTC has, pages of them -- "This will permitted, that will that” -- to make the selectivity which may be required.
The Michigan example is one; the ABA proposal is another.

The ultimate issue which is before you is, are you going to seek to solve this problem by the constitutional bludgeon, or are you gong to permit fine, close work to be done in the states where there is responsibility, too, in dealing with these problems of extending legal services?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: I suppose one answer to one of those questions about Michigan is that Michigan has elected to experiment in one way, and Arizona has elected to experiment in another way.

turn.speaker: john_p_frank
turn.label: Mr. John P. Frank
turn.text: You said it, Mr. Chief Justice, better than I, and it is exactly what I want to say: they are entitled to do it.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, precisely, the reason I made the observation was because of your parade of horribles; that all I asked was whether it was not arguable because one state goes one way and another state goes the other way.

turn.speaker: john_p_frank
turn.label: Mr. John P. Frank
turn.text: It is; but you will notice that all of these proposals are very sharply limited to date.

Now, with the experimentation, it may go further; but what we are really pleading for is, in the desire to solve this problem, let us not destroy the substance of the shared professionalism which we have built up; and I do not apologize for being classical on this score, Mr. Justice Marshall, because we are dealing with a professional tradition of hundreds and hundreds of years.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Hundreds of years ago, you had law offices with a maximum of three lawyers with an income of about $10,000 a year, and now what are we talking about?

turn.speaker: john_p_frank
turn.label: Mr. John P. Frank
turn.text: Well, I am delighted to report to you that at least the incomes have gone up; and some of the offices are bigger, some are not.
I would like to if I may, because I speak here for the profession.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Therefore, (inaudible) for nothing.

turn.speaker: john_p_frank
turn.label: Mr. John P. Frank
turn.text: Frequently, sir, for nothing and frequently took $10 cases; but Abraham Lincoln never made but one ad in his life, and that was to put an announcement in the paper when he returned from Congress to say that his office was open.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But that was a different day and age, obviously.

turn.speaker: john_p_frank
turn.label: Mr. John P. Frank
turn.text: It is a different day and age; but it is an age in which professional tradition has a contribution still to make.
Let me, if I may, conclude on a note of unabashed sentiment. I will not refer to the antitrust subject, merely because it is fully briefed.
I sit here with my partner, Louis.
He has just celebrated his 74th birthday.
His father, with whom he once practiced, was a territorial judge in our state, and the roots of his practice extended back to the 19th Century.
My own father died 40 years ago.
He or I have been members of the Bar of Wisconsin almost for all of this century, my native state.
We have with us today a young lady who assists us as the new breed of legal assistant.
Because of her age, she probably will be linked with the law until the millennium.
The point is that just in this one case on this one side, the professional ties represent 100 consecutive years in the law.
We know the weaknesses of this profession, its limitations and its failures.
So, obviously, do the members of this Court.

We also, all of us, the few at this table, this Court, the lawyers in this room, the thousands outside, and those who came before us, have taken pride in being associated with what is good about this profession; pride in being associated with it.
Minor figures we as individuals may be, but our line runs to Cicero and to Marshall and to Hughes, and we, too, hope that we serve in our small ways.
May it never be said that this profession was cheapened here in this, its highest sanctuary.
Thank you very much.

section.heading: Rebuttal of William C. Canby, Jr.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Frank.
You have a few minutes left.
Do you have anything further, Counsel?

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, just two points.
The material where the name change is discussed appears on Pages 111 and 113 of the record, where Mr. O’Steen is asked whether a lawyer is needed at all with a client.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What page?

turn.speaker: william_c_canby_jr
turn.label: Mr. William C. Canby, Jr.
turn.text: Well, 111 of the record, and I am going on to 113.
I will paraphrase; I will not read this.
And he said, “Well, no, except when it can be done by administrative procedure, going to a department or something, then we send the client on his way with instructions how to do it”.
Then the next question is, “Yes, but nothing in the law requires a person who is getting a judicial name change to go to a lawyer.
Three out of ten in this county go to the court, go to the clerk and do it themselves.
What do you say, then, to that?

The answer was, “Well, we do not know how well it has done, we do not know where instructions exist for this kind of thing; but we do not feel that we have to advise the people that they could do it themselves.”
Now, the final answer to this, of course, is that it does not have anything to do with the ad itself.

If the Bar wants to make a general rule that every attorney should advise every client that all litigants are entitled to handle their matters themselves, then I think that is perfectly proper and all lawyers can be instructed to do it.
But it does not go to the question of what has been advertised in this case.
The ad itself offers a service, and it is not deceptive.
The other point that I would like to make has to do with the comment that the court below found the charge misleading.

The only mention about the expense of a divorce in the lower court’s opinion, the Supreme Court of Arizona’s opinion, is on 12A of our Jurisdictional Statement, which is that blue that is in the Appendix, and it says, “Mr. Justice Gordon, concurring separately, says, ‘Moreover, I am able to foresee instances in which the $175 fee quoted for this service would be unreasonably high.’”

My clients, in addition to the hours they put in, the brief hours on a divorce, have put in, as the record shows, many, many hours devising systems so that they can handle it this briefly, and they also use paralegal time.
If divorces can be had more cheaply than this, let another attorney advertise that fact, and the public will be even better served than they are by my clients.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you, gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
